results.title: The CAAMA Group brochure
results.brief_description: In 1998, the Central Australian Aboriginal Media Association (CAAMA) launched the world’s first Indigenous owned and operated TV network, Imparja Television. Along with the establishment of Indigenous Community Television (ICTV) in 2001, these early initiatives paved the way for today’s broadcasters.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Australia → 07. First Nations First → 04 Birth of Indigenous Broadcasting

results.title: My Survival as an Aboriginal
results.credit_line: Courtesy the Coffey family and Martha Ansara / the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia / Ballad Films
results.brief_description: Essie Coffey OAM was a Murawarri activist, advocate and filmmaker concerned about the influence of white culture and education on Indigenous children. As seen in her groundbreaking documentary, My Survival as an Aboriginal (1978), she taught culture to her community.

constellations_primary.name: Black documentary and truth telling
constellations_primary.description: Essie Coffey was a trailblazer of Indigenous filmmaking, being the first Aboriginal woman to direct a documentary. The film spotlights the outspoken voice Coffey utilised to convey the realities faced by Aboriginal people and to encourage resistance to assimilation.

constellations_other.name: Women in charge
constellations_other.description: Across documentary, film, TV, and visual art, Aboriginal women have led how they will be represented on-screen.

constellations_other.name: Jedda: Uneven ground, the road to on-screen diversity
constellations_other.description: Jedda was the first fully funded Australian feature to be shot on colour film. It was also the first Australian film with Aboriginal actors in lead roles, however, it reflects a deeply problematic time in Australian history.

constellations_other.name: Connecting through film
constellations_other.description: Film acts like a time capsule to our collective past. Capturing our most treasured moments with family has never been more accessible, with technology right at our fingers.

results.description: Essie Coffey OAM was a Murawarri activist, advocate and filmmaker concerned about the influence of white culture and education on Indigenous children. As seen in her groundbreaking documentary, My Survival as an Aboriginal (1978), she taught culture – and the importance of cultural knowledge – to her community. Importantly, her documentary also exposed how First Peoples were marginalised in all aspects of their lives, from school to wider society. The treatment of First Peoples laid bare in her documentary reached wider audiences through screenings at prestigious Australian and international film festivals, where the film won numerous awards. For her dedicated services to the Indigenous Australian community, Coffey herself was awarded an Order of Australia.
description_for_label: Essie Coffey OAM was a Murawarri activist, advocate and filmmaker concerned about the influence of white culture and education on Indigenous children. As seen in her groundbreaking documentary, My Survival as an Aboriginal (1978), she taught culture – and the importance of cultural knowledge – to her community. Importantly, her documentary also exposed how First Peoples were marginalised in all aspects of their lives, from school to wider society. The treatment of First Peoples laid bare in her documentary reached wider audiences through screenings at prestigious Australian and international film festivals, where the film won numerous awards. For her dedicated services to the Indigenous Australian community, Coffey herself was awarded an Order of Australia.
results.credit_line_for_label: Courtesy the Coffey family and Martha Ansara / the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia / Ballad Films

results.title: Basically Black
results.brief_description: Basically Black combined comedy, activism and performing arts while reflecting the political struggles and organising of 1960s and 70s Redfern. The first TV program written and performed by an all-Indigenous cast, this groundbreaking program tackled racism and white paternalism through humour.

constellations_primary.name: Laughing in the face of adversity
constellations_primary.description: Comedy has been used by First Nations storytellers as a tool for social change. On our screens, humour invites audiences to engage with stories and prompts them to grapple with ideas that they otherwise might shy away from.

constellations_other.name: Sequins and sapphires
constellations_other.description: Two of the most striking costumes on the big and small screens embody the glamour of leading First Peoples ladies.

constellations_other.name: Black Power through film and TV
constellations_other.description: The Black Power movement of the late 1960s and early 70s was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the time and later leveraged film and TV to fight for Indigenous rights.

results.description: “Good morning, I am a human being,” Bindi Williams tells the audience during an opening skit of Basically Black (1973). Evolving from the newly established National Black Theatre’s stage production, Basically Black combined comedy, activism and performing arts while reflecting the political struggles and organising of 1960s and 70s Redfern. The first TV program performed by an all-Indigenous cast and led by Blak writers, this groundbreaking program tackled serious issues, like racism and white paternalism, through humour. Despite being well received for its biting satire and commentary, the show didn’t air beyond its premiere. It later emerged that it was considered too political and provocative for the ABC, who had censored parts of the script.
description_for_label: “Good morning, I am a human being,” Bindi Williams tells the audience during an opening skit of Basically Black (1973). Evolving from the newly established National Black Theatre’s stage production, Basically Black combined comedy, activism and performing arts while reflecting the political struggles and organising of 1960s and 70s Redfern. The first TV program performed by an all-Indigenous cast and led by Blak writers, this groundbreaking program tackled serious issues, like racism and white paternalism, through humour. Despite being well received for its biting satire and commentary, the show didn’t air beyond its premiere. It later emerged that it was considered too political and provocative for the ABC, who had censored parts of the script.
